body.p:
Hopkinsville Ky
April 22d 1864
Gov Thos E. Bramlette
Frankfort Ky
Governor

In behalf of a personal friend & a poor but worthy citizen of this town. I have the honor to ask a favor at your hands. I hand you herewith a transcript from the Christian Circuit Court from which it will be seen that McFaddin entered into recognizance bond with J. T. Savage & T. G. Clark his sureties which was forfeited by reason of McFaddin failure to appear.

McFaddin has left the country & his whereabouts are unknown. Clark is utterly insolvent and the whole burden of the forfeiture will fall on Savage- who is an honest
industrious Stone Mason, a worthy citizen in every respect and not worth but little more than the sum named in the bond. A judgment against him would break up his business and ruin him pecuniarily.

He was induced to go in the bond by reason of the fact that McFaddin was working in his employment as stone cutter and gave the most pointed assurances of his purpose to appear in discharge of the recognizance In this he has been deceived & betrayed by McF and now has no hope of deliverance save in Executive interpostition in his behalf
Mr Savage could very readily procure a petition signed by the best citizens of this place but does not deem it necessary.

Your interposition in this case will save a worthy citizen from great oppression if not
absolute ruin and will meet the approbation of all good citizens.

With high regard
I have the honor to be
Yr friend & obt Svt
B. H. Bristow

Christian Cir Ct
vs
J. T. Savage & T. Y. Clarke
$200 --
Remit ^Judgt forfeiture^ except 30 per cent the fees of the Atty for Comth & the costs of prosecution

Tho E Bramlette
send to Bristow
Forfeited Recognizance
27th Apl/64
